title: [ENH] Thoughts on creating a "find my k" sub-module within sktime?
body:
Hey Annotation/Segmentation/Changepoints team!

After a few discussions with you all, it seems like a common problem many of us will need to solve to some degree is "finding k" ie the number of change points segments etc in our data.

One idea I had was that rather than finding k within each of our estimators, it might make sense to separate this logic into a different submodule within `sktime.annotation` that people could import and use in addition to each of our estimators.  

Of the top of my head there are a few approaches to finding k that we might want to consider or support (or perhaps we want to just focus on one?):

- extracting `k` through independent inspection of the data.
       - so this might look like a pre-processing step where we find `k` and pass it to our estimator
- extracting `k` by iteratively fitting each of our estimators for a range of `k` and then returning the best one?
       - this might look more like passing our estimator and data to some sort of `tuning` helper?  Might be able to make use of some of the `GridSearch` functionality that already exists in sktime? (though we might need to configure it so it makes sense for evaluating how well an annotation estimator is performing?) 
- *potentially* we could also consider supporting some probability distribution over the number of segments returned (for example, could be modeled as a dirichlet process or something? 
        - this might also look like a pre-preprocessing step, but then we could imagine calculating an expectation value using our estimators instead of a MLE estimate?
        
Anyway - wanted to loop you all in to the discussion so you could also share any ideas or concerns you might have about this? 

@KatieBuc @fkiraly @lmmentel @NoaBenAmi @lielleravid @Lovkush-A  (please `@` anyone I may have forgotten who would also be interested)
